title: ALT-70 Score for Cellulitis
description: Predicts likelihood of lower extremity cellulitis over other diagnoses (pseudocellulitis). Helps differentiate true cellulitis from its mimics in adult patients presenting to the emergency department with a red leg and clinical concern for cellulitis.

parameters.name: tachycardia
parameters.description: Tachycardia (heart rate ≥90 beats per minute in ED)

ranges.interpretation: Cellulitis unlikely (9% likelihood). Reassess diagnosis and consider pseudocellulitis diagnoses such as venous stasis dermatitis, contact dermatitis, superficial thrombophlebitis, gout, or lymphedema. More than 83.3% likelihood of pseudocellulitis.

Indeterminate (72% likelihood of cellulitis). Consider dermatology or infectious disease consultation to improve diagnostic accuracy, as clinical features alone are insufficient to rule in or rule out cellulitis.
Cellulitis likely (95% likelihood). Treat empirically with appropriate antibiotic therapy for cellulitis. Consider typical cellulitis pathogens (Streptococcus species and Staphylococcus aureus).

references: Raff AB, Weng QY, Cohen JM, Gunasekera N, Okhovat JP, Vedak P, et al. A predictive model for diagnosis of lower extremity cellulitis: a cross-sectional study. J Am Acad Dermatol. 2017 Apr;76(4):618-625.e2. doi: 10.1016/j.jaad.2016.12.044.

Li DG, Dewan AK, Xia FD, Khosravi H, Joyce C, Mostaghimi A. The ALT-70 predictive model outperforms thermal imaging for the diagnosis of lower extremity cellulitis: a prospective evaluation. J Am Acad Dermatol. 2018 Dec;79(6):1076-1080.e1. doi: 10.1016/j.jaad.2018.06.062.

Singer S, Li DG, Gunasekera N, Okhovat JP, Vedak P, Weng C, et al. The ALT-70 cellulitis model maintains predictive value at 24 and 48 hours after presentation. J Am Acad Dermatol. 2019 Dec;81(6):1252-1256. doi: 10.1016/j.jaad.2019.04.008.

Weng QY, Raff AB, Cohen JM, Gunasekera N, Okhovat JP, Vedak P, et al. Costs and Consequences Associated With Misdiagnosed Lower Extremity Cellulitis. JAMA Dermatol. 2017 Feb 1;153(2):141-146. doi: 10.1001/jamadermatol.2016.3816.
formula: ALT-70 Score = (3 × Asymmetric) + (1 × Leukocytosis) + (1 × Tachycardia) + (2 × Age ≥70)
notes: Exclusion criteria: Do not use if patient has visible abscess/fluctuance, penetrating trauma, burn, diabetic ulcer, hardware/device, post-operative patient (surgery within 30 days), recent (within 48 hrs) IV antibiotic use, or known history of osteomyelitis
The ALT-70 score was developed and validated in emergency department settings and may not apply to primary care or other clinical settings
A score of 3-4 is considered indeterminate; consultation with dermatology or infectious disease is recommended for these patients
About 30% of patients admitted to the hospital for cellulitis are misdiagnosed, leading to unnecessary hospitalizations and antibiotic use
Common mimics of cellulitis include venous stasis dermatitis, contact dermatitis, superficial thrombophlebitis, gout, lymphedema, and more serious conditions like DVT or necrotizing fasciitis
